text: Hi, we are seeing a huge uptick in the number of bots clicking links in emails, ads, etc. Our marketing platform is Pardot, CRM = Salesforce, and website is Wordpress - has anyone implemented any solutions that have successfully countered bots?

To me:
• content strategist: SEO-focused, creating a keyword-based strategy for on-site content creation
• content marketer: includes everything that's content marketing, so also social media strategy and content creation, video strategy and creation, etc.

text:
:sparkles:Client onboarding process:sparkles:

Hi all...I'm hoping some of you will share your process with me when a potential client gets in touch for a writing project, as I'd like to solidify my process. Do you schedule a call or just an email? Do you ask them for a brief before giving a quote? Do you send an onboarding document to fill out? Do you always send a contract for every client?

Thanks for any wisdom and insight you are willing to share! :pray:

elements.text: Client onboarding process

Hi all...I'm hoping some of you will share your process with me when a potential client gets in touch for a writing project, as I'd like to solidify my process. Do you schedule a call or just an email? Do you ask them for a brief before giving a quote? Do you send an onboarding document to fill out? Do you always send a contract for every client?

Thanks for any wisdom and insight you are willing to share!

text:
to answer your questions simply:
• start out with email to ask for basic info about the project and the company
• I send a client questionnaire (formal or informal) and ask them to fill it out before scheduling a call
• call is a feeling-out of the client themselves to see if they’re someone i wanna work with, and so they can get a feel for me. i also do a deeper dive into the questionnaire
• I never give a quote on the call. I always give it a day or so to think about it before quoting
• I always send a contract for clients

elements.text: to answer your questions simply:
start out with email to ask for basic info about the project and the company
I send a client questionnaire (formal or informal) and ask them to fill it out before scheduling a call
call is a feeling-out of the client themselves to see if they’re someone i wanna work with, and so they can get a feel for me. i also do a deeper dive into the questionnaire
I never give a quote on the call. I always give it a day or so to think about it before quoting
I always send a contract for clients

text: Thanks so much <@U016BDEQ40J>, that's very helpful! My concern is trying to find the balance between not doing too much work upfront before even getting hired/agreeing to work with the client...but also wanting to be organized and have everything I need from the get go.

elements.text: Thanks so much

, that's very helpful! My concern is trying to find the balance between not doing too much work upfront before even getting hired/agreeing to work with the client...but also wanting to be organized and have everything I need from the get go.

text: also don’t be afraid to move the prospect away from what they are originally proposing. i just spoke to someone who wanted a retainer contract right away but felt he was jumping into things too fast, so i talked him into paying for a couple of trial articles first to make sure he and i were a fit (which he greatly appreciated)

text:
I run an agency, but I've found that giving potential clients the option to ask more questions in an email OR schedule a discovery call on my Calendly has worked well. People who have a lot of qualifying questions will usually ask them in the email, but people who feel confident about moving forward usually go to Calendly.

I use the specific link I set up with ~4 survey questions that help me get a feel for exactly what they need before we meet. In the first 30-minute call, I identify what I need to know and take _copious_ notes.

At that point, I'll either write up a formal proposal or email the client with an idea of what I recommend for them (depending on the use case).

We do use contracts pretty religiously these days. I didn't at first, and in our case it was not a great call. I would say it probably depends on the nature of the work you're doing, but I'm generally a fan of contracts to make sure the expectations and deliverables are very clear up front.

text:
*Hey folks, I’ve a couple of questions re: rate cards.* :slightly_smiling_face: I’ve only given custom quotes at this point, but recently some leads have been asking for rate cards, so I’d like to explore this option.

1. Do you use a rate card? How’s it working for you?

2. When is it a good choice to give your rate card instead of inviting them to a call + creating a custom quote?

3. What’s a good format for a writing rate card?

Thanks in advance!

elements.text: Hey folks, I’ve a couple of questions re: rate cards.

I’ve only given custom quotes at this point, but recently some leads have been asking for rate cards, so I’d like to explore this option.

1. Do you use a rate card? How’s it working for you?

2. When is it a good choice to give your rate card instead of inviting them to a call + creating a custom quote?

3. What’s a good format for a writing rate card?

Thanks in advance!
